description: From English dialectal hyke (“to walk vigorously”), probably a Northern form of hitch, from Middle English hytchen, hichen, icchen (“to move, jerk, stir”). Cognate with Scots hyke (“to move with a jerk”), dialectal German hicken (“to hobble, walk with a limp”), Danish hinke (“to hop”). More at hick.

entries.meaning: A long walk, usually for pleasure or exercise. [from c. 1900]

examples: Antonym: cut (used in same context); decrease
The tenants were not happy with the rent hike.

entries.meaning: (American football) The snap of the ball to start a play.
A sharp upward tug to raise something.
examples: She gave a cute hike of her skirt as she spun and almost sauntered down the stairs.

verbs.description: hike (third-person singular simple present hikes, present participle hiking, simple past and past participle hiked)

entries.meaning: To take a long walk for pleasure or exercise.
examples: Don't forget to bring the map when we go hiking tomorrow.

entries.meaning: To unfairly or suddenly raise a price.
(American football) To snap the ball to start a play.
(nautical) To lean out to the windward side of a sailboat in order to counterbalance the effects of the wind on the sails.
To pull up or tug upwards sharply.
